title: Information services: competition and externalities
descriptions:
The proposed project, titled "Information services: competition and externalities," aims to foster knowledge of the economics of information services by studying strategic interactions, production and exchange of information services, and externalities. The project will focus on understanding one-sided or two-sided network externalities, information as a public good, and the complements of information services and physical infrastructures at both the content and physical infrastructure levels.

The project consists of four parts: background theory, virtual layer, physical layer, and competition policy. Each part will explore specific topics related to externalities in information services, such as two-sided markets, recommendation systems, pricing, and net-neutrality. The approach will involve developing relevant theory, conducting empirical investigations using proprietary data from e-commerce platforms, creating original dynamic investment models, and providing tools for competition policy makers.

Overall, this project will contribute to the understanding of the role of externalities in the economics of information services, providing insights that can inform policy decisions and industry practices in this rapidly evolving sector.
